docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Whether you are a beginner or an experienced developer, this page provides valuable insights, helpful tutorials, and expert advice to make the most out of your Raspberry Pi. Explore various guides on setup, programming, troubleshooting, and advanced projects, and enhance your skills in building innovative solutions with this powerful and versatile mini-computer. Let’s dive in and start making your Raspberry Pi experience even better!

docs.title: CPU Frequency Scaling
docs.text:
Raspbian, by default, sets the CPU frequency to a fixed 700MHz. For use cases where maximum CPU power is not always needed, reducing the CPU frequency can be reasonable.

The following steps describe how to lower the CPU frequency during idle times. (This may have limited effects, so consider it an exploration of technical interest.)

docs.title: GPU Configuration
docs.text:
/boot/config.txt is read by the GPU before the CPU starts up, and it contains settings for CPU frequency as well. Add the following lines:

Bash
# Enable CPU frequency scaling
force_turbo=0
# Set minimum CPU frequency (default is 700)
arm_freq_min=100

A reboot is required for these changes to take effect.

For more details, refer to: RPiconfig - eLinux.org

docs.title: Linux Kernel Configuration
docs.text:
By modifying the GPU settings, the CPU gains frequency scaling capabilities. However, the Linux kernel has its own control mechanisms, which by default lock the CPU frequency at 100MHz.

You can check the current, maximum, and minimum CPU frequencies using the following commands:

  • Current CPU frequency: Bash
    cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/cpuinfo_cur_freq
  • Maximum CPU frequency: Bash
    cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/cpuinfo_max_freq
  • Minimum CPU frequency: Bash
    cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/cpuinfo_min_freq

The Linux kernel includes a CPU frequency governor that determines how frequency changes occur. By default, Raspbian uses the powersave governor.

Available governors: - performance: Always runs at the maximum CPU frequency. - powersave: Always runs at the minimum CPU frequency. - ondemand: Adjusts frequency based on CPU load (Raspbian toggles between min and max only). - conservative: Smoothly adjusts frequency based on CPU load. - userspace: Allows user-space daemons to control the CPU frequency.

These settings can be changed during runtime via sysfs:

Bash
echo ondemand > /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_governor

To make this setting persist after reboot, there are two options:

  1. Adding the command to /etc/rc.local

  2. This method executes the command after the kernel boots, which may result in a longer boot time.

  3. Enabling kernel configuration options:

  4. Enable the following kernel options: Bash
    CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_DEFAULT_GOV_ONDEMAND
CONFIG_CPU_FREQ_DEFAULT_GOV_CONSERVATIVE
  5. This method requires rebuilding the kernel but ensures full CPU power during boot.

After these settings are applied, you should observe CPU frequency changes based on system load. Give it a try!

docs.title: How to Create Docker Image of Raspbian
docs.text: This guide explains how to create a Docker image for Raspbian on Ubuntu/Debian.

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text:
First, download the Raspbian OS image and unzip it:

Bash
wget https://downloads.raspberrypi.com/raspios_lite_armhf/images/raspios_lite_armhf-2024-11-19/2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.img.xz
unzip 2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.img.xz

docs.title: Inspect the OS Image
docs.text:
Use fdisk to inspect the image and identify partitions. We need Sector size and Start Sector of second image for mount. Bash

sudo fdisk --list 2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.img
Disk 2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.img: 2.38 GiB, 2550136832 bytes, 4980736 sectors
Units: sectors of 1 * 512 = 512 bytes
Sector size (logical/physical): 512 bytes / 512 bytes
I/O size (minimum/optimal): 512 bytes / 512 bytes
Disklabel type: dos
Disk identifier: 0x57b902f5

Device                                      Boot   Start     End Sectors  Size Id Type
2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.img1         8192 1056767 1048576  512M  c W95 FAT32 (LBA)
2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.img2      1056768 4980735 3923968  1.9G 83 Linux

docs.title: Mount and Create Docker Image
docs.text:
Bash
mkdir image
sudo mount -o loop,offset=$((512*1056768)) 2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.img image
cd image
sudo tar cf ../docker-image-2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.tar .

Import the archive as a Docker image: Bash

docker import docker-image-2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite.tar raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite:2024-11-19

Check if the image is registered: Bash

docker image list

docs.title: Install qemu
docs.text:
If your host is x86_64, enable ARM emulation: Bash

sudo apt-get -y install qemu-user-static

docs.title: Running the Docker Image
docs.text:
Run the container: Bash

docker run -it raspios-bookworm-armhf-lite:2024-11-19 /bin/bash
uname -a
Linux f5f38b46dc55 6.1.0-31-amd64 #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Debian 6.1.128-1 (2025-02-07) armv7l GNU/Linux

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This guide outlines creating a Docker image from a Raspbian image, importing it into Docker, and running it with QEMU emulation on non-ARM hosts.

docs.title: How to move rootfs to external USB storage
docs.text: This guide explains how to move the root filesystem (rootfs) of a Raspberry Pi running Bookworm to an external USB storage device.

docs.title: 1. Prepare Your External USB Storage
docs.text:
Bash
sudo fdisk /dev/sdX
# Create a new partition (type Linux) and format it
sudo mkfs.ext4 /dev/sdX1

docs.title: 2. Mount the USB Storage
docs.text:
Bash
sudo mkdir /mnt/usb
sudo mount /dev/sdX1 /mnt/usb

docs.title: 3. Copy RootFS to USB
docs.text:
Bash
sudo rsync -aAXv / --exclude={"/dev/*","/proc/*","/sys/*","/tmp/*","/run/*","/mnt/*","/media/*","/lost+found"} /mnt/usb

docs.title: 4. Modify Boot Configuration
docs.text:
Bash

sudo nano /boot/cmdline.txt
Change the root= parameter to point to your USB device, e.g., root=/dev/sdX1.

docs.title: 5. Reboot the Raspberry Pi
docs.text:
Bash
sudo sync
sudo reboot

Your Raspberry Pi should now boot from the external USB storage.

docs.title: Optimizing Swap with ZRAM on Raspbian
docs.text: By default, Raspbian uses a swap file on the SD card, which can reduce performance and shorten the card's lifespan. ZRAM is a solution that creates a compressed swap partition in RAM, improving both performance and longevity.

docs.title: Disable Default Swap Setting
docs.text:
Bash
sudo apt-get install chkconfig
sudo chkconfig dphys-swapfile off

docs.title: Enable Swap on ZRAM
docs.text:
1. Load the ZRAM module: Bash

    sudo modprobe zram

  2. Set a 128MB ZRAM swap space: Bash

    echo $((128*1024*1024)) | sudo tee /sys/zram0/disksize

  3. Create and enable the swap: Bash

    sudo mkswap /dev/zram0
sudo swapon -p 10 /dev/zram0

With ZRAM enabled, your Raspberry Pi will benefit from faster swap performance and reduced SD card wear.

Enjoy optimizing your Raspberry Pi!

docs.title: Power Saving on Raspbian
docs.text: Raspbian allows you to optimize settings for better power efficiency. This guide focuses on methods to reduce energy consumption, making your Raspberry Pi more efficient for battery-powered or always-on projects.

docs.title: Check Current CPU Frequency
docs.text:
Bash
cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_cur_freq

docs.title: Set CPU Governor to 'powersave'
docs.text:
Bash
sudo cpufreq-set -g powersave

docs.title: Set Maximum CPU Frequency
docs.text:
Bash
sudo cpufreq-set -u 600000

docs.title: Disable HDMI to Save Power
docs.text:
Bash
sudo /usr/bin/tvservice -o

docs.title: Turn Off Unused USB Devices
docs.text:
Bash
echo '1-1' | sudo tee /sys/bus/usb/drivers/usb/unbind

docs.title: Reduce GPU Memory Allocation
docs.text:
Bash
sudo nano /boot/config.txt
# Add or modify:
gpu_mem=16

Applying these settings can significantly reduce power consumption, ideal for headless setups or long-term operations.

Happy optimizing your Raspberry Pi! ⚡

docs.title: Static IP Configuration on Raspbian (Bookworm)
docs.text: Setting a static IP address on Raspbian Bookworm ensures your Raspberry Pi always uses the same IP, simplifying remote access.

docs.title: 1. Open the NetworkManager Configuration
docs.text:
Bash
sudo nmcli connection show

docs.title: 2. Modify the Connection to Set a Static IP
docs.text:
Bash

sudo nmcli connection modify "Wired connection 1" ipv4.addresses 192.168.1.100/24
sudo nmcli connection modify "Wired connection 1" ipv4.gateway 192.168.1.1
sudo nmcli connection modify "Wired connection 1" ipv4.dns "8.8.8.8 8.8.4.4"
sudo nmcli connection modify "Wired connection 1" ipv4.method manual
Replace 192.168.1.100 with your desired IP, and adjust the gateway and DNS settings as needed.

docs.title: 3. Save and Apply the Configuration
docs.text:
Bash
sudo nmcli connection up "Wired connection 1"

docs.title: 4. Verify the Static IP
docs.text:
Bash

ip addr show eth0
Check that the IP address matches your static configuration.

Your Raspberry Pi is now set with a static IP address using NetworkManager! 🌐
